discourse_list.title: Should MakerDAO/DAI run Simultaneously on another Chain?

content.content: We all know it is becoming very difficult for the average user to participate in Decentralized Finance via Ethereum. Current users are paying the highest transaction fees on the Ethereum network. So, what do we do? Do we wait it out and hope that Eth 2.0 will resolve the issue at hand and hope that it does resolve itself and allows the average user to regain confidence? Or do we seriously think about what Tarun Chitra said recently that some chains like Solana are trying to pull the Carriage with 1 Horse, but others like Eth are trying to pull the Carriage with 10, 24 Chickens? For sure, It’s a complex software problem. And if we do wait, what are the odds that another Mempool Manipulation consisting of Hammerbots, Mempool Compression, and Spontaneous Stuck Transactions occurs? I would think very high, at odds of 1/5. Do we sit around and wait, or do we research as a community for other options? And as a community–do we believe DAI will only live on Ethereum? And will Ethereum be the only chain to rule them All? I recently saw a twitter post by @monet-supply that he made a transaction on Cosmos for $0.01, or perhaps it was less.  Now I have never used any other chain besides Ethereum, nor am I technically qualified to ask if we should look at running the MakerDAO protocol on another chain–key word: Simultaneously – but I do know a thing or two about user experience, customer retention, and product-market fit. And right now, we just aren’t cutting it. Simple and plain. And when we do figure out what Chain has the most product-market fit, it will be too late. DeFi has product-market fit, but it still not approachable. My question to the community–when do we start looking at running MakerDAO simultaneously on other chains? And if it’s possible, would it help regulate the promise of a Stable Peg? I’m not picking chains, because I don’t use anything else, but Ethereum–I do know that the playing field right now is tilted towards one side. And it does not favour the average Jane & Joe. In fact, it starting to feel like a Casino for the wealthy… Place your bets on Black, or Red—and here we go…

content.content: So, it would be considerably difficult to pull the core protocol over to another chain at the moment; however, I think exploring DAI on other chains and on L2 is a really good idea.  L2 for DAI can radically reduce costs for simple trading and transactions of DAI. Additionally, and more on a medium horizon, it seems RenVM is looking at exporting assets from Ethereum to other chains and DAI seemed like a priority for them.

content.content: do you have any documentation on this ren project?
The RenVM Technical Overview is a good place to start. Some of the Ren team are on this forum, if you have questions try posting here.

I think L2 solutions that can handle the complexity of a Maker vault are still quite far out on the horizon so it’s unlikely that L2 will make borrowing and interacting with MakerDAO cheaper. I do see however that token transfers should become much more practical to do off chain quite soon. I don’t think just waiting for Eth2 to come around or these L2 solutions to become advanced enough to allow for large parts of MCD to run off chain is a viable alternative though. Which in my opinion only leaves us with two options:  accept that borrowing from MakerDAO will for the foreseeable future cost $10-20. deploy MCD to another more scalable chain  It’s likely that a large enough user-base of MakerDAO will still accept borrowing at >100gwei gas prices but it will price out the people that want to borrow DAI 1000 at a time. There are collateral-backed stablecoin projects out there that are building on other chains. None of them are as mature as MakerDAO of course but this could become an interesting space. Acala.network is a project that’s been building a system very similar to Maker’s. Many chains have EVM support (that’s how Aragon for example is planning on offering DAOs on their own cosmos based chain) so merely deploying the contracts would be quite easy. The infrastructure around it is where it gets harder:  Trying to make Eth-based DAI and other DAI fungible is unlikely Governance effort would almost double as these systems are largely decoupled Eth-DAI has a huge amount of support by exchanges and other integrators. That work would have to start from scratch with other chains  With current gas prices though, my gut’s telling me that by now it’s more of a question of when we will start having these serious discussion not if. Is it $275/ETH & 100Gwei or is it $1000/ETH & 200Gwei? Because of that, I think its only prudent to start researching how a multi-chain makerdao could look like. What RenVM will allow others to do is to at least move both collateral and DAI across different chains more freely. That doesn’t lower the cost of interacting with a vault and therefore will make MakerDAO less accessible for smaller borrowers but at least it will allow interacting with assets that exist on other chains because Ethereum might be too expensive and it will allow DAI to be used in other chains.

content.content: I would not move the core protocol on another chain, because after it got deployed on another chain, the maintenance effort would increase exponentially and there could be some security issues that harm the project. Why not a L2 solution by porting the DAI to IOTA smart contracts?! In such a scenario the DAI could be the currency to empower the machine 2 machine economy on IOTA. Feeless smart contracts and free transactions are big step towards mainstream and especially industry adoption. Don’t understand me wrong, I definetly see the DeFi core on Ethereum where Maker delivers the heartbeat, but why not providing the DAI as the base protocol for Open Industrial Finance (OIF)? I think it’s better to bring the DAI as a L2 solution into the game than to wait and leave the OIF market to another player (EUR,…).

Current users are paying the highest transaction fees on the Ethereum network.   AFAIK this is nothing new and was always expected. Ethereum does not have any transaction complexity bias (miners have no incentives to include transactions with lower gas usage first). I am not following ETH 2.0 development, but i will assume nothing will change (bandwith increase is only kicking the bucket further). Other chains probably work the same, it’s just that they are not used.

content.content: After reading through this post I still don’t think this is a good fit for maker. The robustness of the iota protocol is still questionable, and what we really want is a layer 2 solution on ethereum, not a layer 2 solution on a different blockchain. A solution like xdai would be much more appropriate for us, and there are likely other solutions out there as well. I don’t think we should add support for an entirely new blockchain until it’s proven enough that there’s demand on chains other than ethereum. It really does seem like cryptocurrency use cases are starting to converge on ethereum

content.content: @ma_ki  Totally–and I’m sure the Maker Foundation and the Dev Team have looked in to such–recently they had a Hackathon, or two with regards to L2 solutions. I think eventually DAI will run on other Chains–you have NEAR protocol building the ETH-NEAR Rainbow bridge https://bit.ly/31hpIXG You also have other chains wanting to come over to Ethereum–as an example, the Algorand community has proposed a Wrapped ALGO (wALGO) that allows folks over there to bring their ALGO tokens over and use in the ETH DeFi world. There’s also Serum (FTX people) being built on Solana. It’s an order book DEX, that will swap in less than 1 second–we shall see if that is the case. They claim you’ll be able to use your MetaMask on Serum for Ethereum Tokens, and you’ll have the choice to swap DAI from an Ethereum to a Solana address. But of course, these are All experiments and we’ll have to wait and see if it does work out. Let’s not forget PolkaDot. All in all–a lot of exciting innovations are happening
